Faeziddin B. is continuing to bake the Tajik national flatbread. Faeziddin used his first KIVA loan to purchase flour and a bicycle with a trailer. He paid back his loan on time and showed himself to be an exemplary client. Recently his daughter got married. Today, Faeziddin would like to take out a loan to purchase flour at wholesale.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Фаезиддин продолжает заниматься выпечкой национальных лепешек. Свой первый займ от КИВА Фаезиддин направил покупку муки и основных средств - велосипеда с тележкой. Все погашения предыдущего займа произвел вовремя и показал себя образцовым клиентом. Недавно он также выдал свою дочь замуж. Сейчас Фаезиддин хочет получить новый для оптового закупа муки.

loans.use: Purchase flour

loans.name: Yao

texts.fr:
A young building draftsman by profession, Mr. Yao A. was not able to open his own office, and began selling generic products – in particular GNLD (Golden Neo-Life Diamite) products – in order to provide for his two children and his wife. Hoping to increase his supply, he is requesting a loan to better accomplish his goals. Such a loan will have a great financial impact on his family given the significant increase in profit that he will have earned.

Translated from French by Erin Johnson, Kiva Volunteer.

Jeune dessinateur bâtiment de profession, Monsieur A. Yao n’étant pas en mesure d’ouvrir son propre cabinet, il s’est lancé dans la vente des produits génériques spécialement les GND (Golden Neonlife Diamite) pour pouvoir subvenir aux besoins de sa famille de deux enfants et une femme. Voulant augmenter sa capacité d’approvisionnement, il sollicite un crédit pour mieux réaliser son projet. Ce crédit ainsi débloqué aura une grande répercussion financière dans sa famille sans oublier la nette augmentation du profit réalisé auparavant.

loans.use: Purchase and sale of generic products.

loans.name: Mariana

texts.es:
Mariana is married and has 2 children. Facing the need to cover the family expenses, five years ago she started selling shoes by catalogue to her friends and family. Little by little her sales started to increase and soon, her customers started to request she sell clothing as well. In this manner she has been expanding her business and every day her roster of clients grows even more.

She requests a loan in the amount of $1000 US that she will repay in a term of 6 months. She will use the funds to purchase merchandise and offer her clients a greater seletionof clothing and shoes. With your help she will be a success.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

Mariana es casada y tiene 2 hijos, ante la necesidad de apoyar en los gastos familiares, hace 5 años empezó a vender entre sus conocidos zapatos por catalogo, poco a poco sus ventas fueron incrementando y comenzaron a pedirle que vendiera ropa de esta manera ella ha ido creciendo en el negocio y cada día su cartera de clientes crece mas.

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $1000 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar mercancia y poder ofrecerle a sus clientes mas variedad en ropa y zapatos. Con tu ayuda ella saldra adelante.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Lim

texts.en:
Mr. Lim V., 34, is a vegetable farmer in Serey Sokhom Village in the Kampong Cham Province. His wife, Mrs. El Kimsun, helps him on the farm. The couple has two children, both are enrolled in the local school.

They own a half hectar which is a large piece of land for them to work by themselves. In order to cultivate the vegetables, Mr. Lim V. decided to ask for loan to hire a laborer to work with them in the field. His wife is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To hire a laborer to help cultivate vegetables in the field.

loans.name: Afi

texts.fr:
Née à Lomé en 1957, Mme A. Afi est mariée et mère de cinq enfants. En plus de ces derniers, elle a également deux autres enfants de sa sœur aînée à charge. Très dynamique et appréciée dans son quartier pour sa bonne moralité, Mme A. Afi vend les produits de première nécessité et des beignets.
 
La qualité de ses beignets lui a valu une clientèle assez nombreuse. Son chiffre d’affaire étant bas à cause du manque de moyens, elle n’arrive pas à satisfaire tout le monde. 

Elle sollicite un crédit pour s'approvisionner en  produits de premières nécessité et en matières premières
texts.en:
Born in Lomé in 1957, Afi A. is married and the mother of five children. In addition, she cares for her sister’s two children. Very energetic and known in the neighborhood for her good character, Afi sells the basic necessities and fritters. A large number of customers are drawn to the quality of her fritters, but due to a lack of resources her sales are low and she is unable to meet the demand. Afi is requesting a loan to stock up on merchandise and ingredients.

Translated from French by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock up on basic necessities and ingredients

loans.name: Araceli

texts.en:
Araceli J. C. is a member of the Wiracocha (“Sun God”) Village Bank. She is married with one 16-year-old son and a baby on the way. 

Araceli runs an educational daycare center for children ages 0-6 in Santa Elena, a village outside of the city of Ayacucho, Peru. She has been in this business for the past four years, and her business has grown bit by bit. She used to run the center from her home, then moved to another facility when the daycare outgrew her home. Now, she is planning to open an even larger daycare center in the center of Ayacucho. She is currently in the process of formalizing her business, along with her investment partner.

Araceli is requesting a loan of 1000 soles ($325 USD) to buy rugs and ceramic tile for her daycare center. She says it will be a different kind of daycare, more responsive to the needs of a modern family. She will pick up kids at their homes so their parents don’t have to worry about dropping them off, and also plans to offer educational classes for expectant mothers. 

Araceli’s baby is due on November 24th. She jokingly calls him her “first student.” She hopes to see her business grow more and more in the future so that she can continue to support her children and their education. Her older son hopes to go to medical school in Lima next year.

loans.use: Buy carpeting for daycare center

loans.name: Koffi

texts.en: Koffi Ewe T. is 33 years of age, married and has 2 children.  In the local language, Ewe, his first name indicates that he was born on Friday.  Koffi lives in the village of Wome, a small town approximately 130 kilometers from Lomé, the Togolese capital.  To provide for his family, Koffi picks up passengers along the road with his motorcycle and drops them off at their destination.  This service is always in demand in Wome as there is no electricity in this village and people must often travel further than walking distance.  Koffi has asked for this loan through Kiva, so that he can buy a new motorcycle. This would allow him to provide a better service to his customers.  With the profits he will earn from his business, Koffi can continue to send his children to school and provide for his wife and family.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Gakuweebwamunno Lending Group

texts.en:
Christine N. is the chairperson of Gakuweebwa Munno women’s group in Lugazi. She has over 10 years business experience in selling new clothes for men, women and children at daily markets locally termed as “mubuulo.” Using her loans from Pearl Microfinance, Christine is able to boost her clothing business by buying more clothes by the bale, hence providing her customers with variety, as she comes to Kampala twice a week for shopping.

She is married with four children and stays with her children since her husband stays and works in Kenya. This means that she cares for her children and dependants, and only considers their father as the head of the family. She believes that without borrowing, waiting for funds from her husband would have made her life hard.

loans.use: Increased stock for her clothing selling business.

loans.name: Efe

texts.en: Efe a 45 years old and married with 5 children. She sells provisions. She needs a loan in the amount of N80, 000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Kokadie Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Kokadjè sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent  en majorité dans des  familles traditionnelles polygames à TDJILA situé dans la sous préfecture de NIENA de la 3ème région administrative du Mali. Elles menent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres l’achat - vente de céréales, de canaris,d’arachide.
Elles sont à leur premier prêt (prêt solidaire avec Soro Yiriwaso et  comptent acheter avec ce prêt, 5sacs de 100kg de céréales, 2 sacs de 100 kilogrammes d’arachide et 20 canaris, au marché de KOUGNA,de TIEKOUNKO de BOUGOULABA et de TDJILA. Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de KOUGNA,de TIEKOUNKO de BOUGOULABA et de TDJILA.  en détail au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 5.000FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie  investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women in the Kokadjè group are all married and average 33 years of age and 4 children. Most of them live in polygamous traditional families in Tdjila, located in the subprefecture of Niena (third administrative region of Mali). They run diverse businesses, such as, among others : buying and selling cereals, "canaris" (a container used to cook food) and peanuts.

They are seeking their first group loan (solidarity loan) with Kiva's partner Soro Yiriwaso, and intend to use it to buy 5 100-kilogram sacks of cereals, 2 100-kilogram sacks of peanuts, and 20 "canaris" at the Kougna, Tiekounko, Bougoulaba and Tdjila markets. The goods are sold in the same markets, for cash and on credit, to a clientele comprising men and women. They foresee turning an average monthly profit of XOF 5'000 (ca US$ 10) each, to be in part used to provide for their families, and in part invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell various items (cereals, peanuts, cookware, ...)

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
This is Ibrahim K., a local entrepreneur in Makeni City. Ibrahim is requesting a loan in order to give strength to his business. Ibrahim is a welder and would like to get a loan in order to buy working materials like metals, iron bars, etc.

Ibrahim is forty-two, married with five children. Four of his children are in secondary school and the last one is in nursery school. He was born in a small town called Kamabai about twenty-two miles from Makeni City. Ibrahim has been in the welding business for over fifteen years now. 

This will be the second loan Ibrahim will be receiving from KIVA through SMT. The previous loan made a tremendous impact on the life of this entrepreneur. With this new loan, Ibrahim will feel very good as it will enable his business to flourish, he told me.

loans.use: Buy working materials

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita L., 50, of Jimenez, is married to a welder mechanic. They are blessed with one child who is a second year high school student.

The earnest desire of the couple is to see their only son finish college and have a bright future ahead. And so, hard work and patience are the only keys they have had.

Teresita joined Paglaum to access finances for additional capital for snack vending so she can help her husband and make money in her own way. Her customers are her neighbors, cousins and nearby canteens.

loans.use: Buy snack vending items to sell.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en: Mrs. Alma R. E. of P8 San Antonio, Ozamiz City is an active member of the PAGLAUM MPC. Her husband is a Government Employee as a Draftsman in the City Engineers Office. Even if her husband is regularly employed, supporting the studies of her children is hard to do. She was previously engaged in buying and selling prawns and a Prawn Hatchery operation but failed.  Presently, she is engaged in NFA rice retailing under the Tindahan Natin Program of the government. She started this business with an initial capital of P5,000.00 from her relatives and friends a year ago. Her customers were her neighbors and close friends. Now she is expanding by delivering her sacks of rice to different stores in their area and neighboring places in Mis. Occ. Now on her second loan, she is applying for PHP 10,000.00 for additional capital for her existing business. Her future plan is to establish an outlet in the city and to give continuous support for her children's education. These hopes and aspirations will come true with the help of KIVA and PAGLAUM.

loans.use: Additonal capital for NFA rice retailing business

location.town: Ozamis-P8 San Antonio, Ozamiz City, Mis. Occ.

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
Mercedes es socia del Banco Comunal Orquídeas.
Mercedes es conviviente, tiene 26 años y 1 hijo, Mercedes vende golosinas en la puerta de una empresa de transportes, para lo cual cuenta con un triciclo, actividad que realiza todos los días.
Mercedes necesita un préstamo de 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de galletas y gaseosas.
Los sueños de Mercedes son mejorar sus negocios, ahorrar para sacar adelante a sus hijos y brindarles lo mejor.
texts.en:
Mercedes is a member of the communal bank Orquídeas. She lives with her partner, is 26 years old, and has a son. Everyday Mercedes sells sweets in the doorway of a transportation business, which is why she has the use of a tricycle. Mercedes needs a loan of 600 soles that she will invest in the purchase of cookies and soft drinks. Mercedes dreams of improving her business and saving so she can help her kids get ahead and give them the best.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Mercedes necesita un préstamo de 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de galletas y gaseosas.

loans.name: Sandra

texts.es: Sandra tiene 21 años, junto a su esposo trabajan duro para la construcción de su casa, la cual está a punto de concluir. Ella se dedica a la venta de comida junto a una tía, con quien viene trabajando por más de 2 años, y en el tiempo que viene realizando esta actividad aprendió a preparar diversidad de platos. Es así que todos los días sale por la mañana a preparar los alimentos en la casa de su tía, donde también está instalado el pequeño restaurante donde trabajan hasta altas horas de la noche, ya que a esas horas tienen mayor cantidad de clientes. Con sus ahorros, Sandra tiene pensado  invertir en la compra de un carrito de comida para vender en la puerta de su casa, y este es el motivo por el que solicita este préstamo, para completar el monto necesario. Para el futuro quiere instalar un restaurante en su domicilio para estar más cerca de su familia.
texts.en:
Sandra is 21 years old. Sandra and her husband have been working hard to build a house and are almost done. To make a living, Sandra sells food with her aunt. They have been working together for 2 years and in this time Sandra has learned to make many different dishes. Sandra goes to her aunt’s house every morning to prepare food. Her aunt has a small restaurant in her home and Sandra works there late into the night because late a night they have more customers. Sandra is planning to buy a food cart with her savings so she can sell from her front door. This is why she is requesting a loan, so she can get the rest of the money necessary. In the future, she would like to have a restaurant in her home so she can be closer to her family.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de un carrito de comida

loans.name: Ourn

texts.en: Mrs. Ourn N. lives in Preak Traeng village in Kandal province. She sells Khmer cake and juice sugar. She also is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. On her plantation, she faces a problem because she does not have rice seed to grow in the field. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed for growing and to use the rest of the money to buy a cart for her family. Mrs. Ourn N. is 44 years old and the mother of a child who is a chop wood seller.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and a cart.

loans.name: Alofamoni

texts.en:
Alofamoni W., 30, is married with four children. She has many years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the public and villagers three days per week and expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD). She has no previous loan with SPBD.

SPBD loans are Alofamoni’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She is very appreciative of the financial help she receives from the program, and wishes to stay in the program for a long time.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, tools and chemicals needed for good growth

loans.name: Aktam

texts.en:
This is K. Aktam. He is married with 5 children. K. is filled with enthusiasm and works hard preparing and selling the a local pie called “sambusa” . In a small place which he rents, he makes the pies with course flour and meat baked in coals according to the old recipes.  He has big plans and dreams of improving his business. When he was very young, Aktam learned a great deal about sambusa preparation from his mother and that is why he decided to dedicate himself to this work. His goal is to have his own place where he can offer more comforts to his customers, and he'd like to buy a refrigerator so he can begin to offer cold drinks as well. Aktam is requesting an individual loan of 3000 Somoni. He wants to purchase the necessary supplies of foodstuffs for preparing  “sambusa” pies and also to improve his business. He is very motivated to grow his business and increase his income. With his efforts, and your important contribution, Aktam can reach his goals. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase supplies of foodstuffs for preparing  “sambusa” pies and improve his business.

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia, or Amy as she is called in her village in Inaban Dupax del Norte, is married to Rolly. They have seven children, four girls and three boys. Their two older children are college undergraduates and already married, while the other five children are still studying in high school and elementary school.  

The couple is in the farming business. They are striving hard to earn a living and to further support the education of their children. At present, Amy would like to borrow a loan of PHP 10,000 from Kiva lenders. She will use the loan for the maintenance of their farm and to purchase enough farm supplies for them to have a good harvest. Amy hopes that someday, their business will grow and they can improve their living situation.

loans.use: Farm maintenance and purchase of farm supplies

location.town: Inaban Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Mafisa Group

texts.en:
Anna is a member of the Mafisa borrower group in Msamvu,Morogoro,she is 34 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 4 children.Her children are aged 16,7,4 and 2 years.

Anna started her own cafe business 6 years ago,she works 12 hours a day earn monthly profit approximately 90,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Anna`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more commodities like rice,cooking oil,sugar.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Anna hopes to save more money,pay school fess and expand her business.

Naluzsiye is also the member of the same borrower group in Mafisa,she also requested the loan amount 150,000 Tsh in order to expand her food business

loans.use: To buy more rice,sugar,cooking oil for food

loans.name: Sabaly Group

texts.fr:
Sabaly est un regroupement composé de  5 femmes mariées, une veuve et une femme divorcée qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 38ans ont en moyenne 4 enfants et vivent dans des  familles monogames à Mancourani Natien un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur septième  prêt solidaire après avoir remboursés les six précédents. 
Elles font comme activités économiques la vente de pagnes real, des jus de fabrication locale, des tomates et de divers articles de boutique (huile, sucre, savons etc).
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 6 paniers de tomates, 10 sacs de gingembre, 1 sac de sucre, 1 bidon de 20 litres d’huile alimentaire et 3 cartons de savons . Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville le jour de foire auprès des grossistes. 
Elles vendent au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à la maison et aux marchés, à une clientèle composée de forains mais aussi  de la population locale.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 45.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Certaines d’entre elles comptent acheter un terrain à usage d’habitation et d’autres d’acheter un attelage pour les déplacements dans les villages avoisinants.
texts.en:
Sabaly is a group of 5 married women, one widow and one divorced woman, with an average age of 38 and on average, 4 children. They mostly live in monogamous families in Mancourani Natien, one of the neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso, 3rd administrative region of Mali. They are on their 7th solidarity loan, working together with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution, with the intention of satisfying their customers’ needs. Their previous 6 loans were correctly reimbursed.

They have various businesses such as selling “Real” African waxcloth, locally produced juices, tomatoes, and various dry goods (oil, sugar, soap, etc.) With their new loan, they intend to buy 6 baskets of tomatoes, 10 sacks of ginger, 1 sack of sugar, 1 jerrycan of 20 liters of cooking oil, and 3 cartons of soaps. They do their buying in the big market of Sikasso town, on weekly marketdays, from wholesalers. The goods are sold for cash, retail, and for credit, out of their homes and in the markets, to a clientele composed itinerant merchants but also of local people.

They each expect to make a monthly average profit of 45,000 F CFA, of which a part will be used for savings and for family expenses and the rest invested back into their businesses. Certain members intend to buy a lot to use to build a family house on and others hope to buy a donkey cart to use when they go to neighboring villages.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Hog raising is the sole source of income of Arlyn’s family. Arlyn is married to Flor, Jr. and the couple is blessed with a boy named Flor III who is nine years old and already in elementary level.

Arlyn is aiming to improve their poor standard of living so that she can further sustain the needs of her family. She hopes to give her family a progressive living by properly maintaining her hog-raising business that her husband helps her to manage.

Arlyn hopes to borrow PHP 4,000 from Kiva lenders that she will use to purchase hog feed till her pigs became fully grown. She wants to buy her stock of feed in order ensure the growth of her livestock.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed

loans.name: Ismatullo

texts.ru: Исматулло Примов проживает в районе Турсунзаде. Возраст 41 год. Женат, имеет 2 детей. По специальности Исматулло проработал "электромантером" более 2 лет. Вот более 2 лет занимается торвлей на рынке. Он в основном торгует бакалеей, т.е. рисом, чичевицей, горохом и т.д. Кредит просит для увеличения товараоборота.

loans.use: Увеличение товараоборота

loans.name: Gombosuren

texts.en: P. is 48 years old and lives with her husband and two children in a house in the Arkhangai province of Mongolia. Both of her children attend the university and her husband helps her with the family business. P. operates a dairy retail business at the local market. She began the business in 2006 with working capital of 800,000 tugrugs. Since then, her business has become very successful and her working capital now exceeds 3,500,000 tugrugs. Because her business has become so successful, her family has been able to build their own home, purchase a car, and are in the process of building a home for her oldest child. P. is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase more milk and dairy products in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more milk and dairy products

loans.name: Phou

texts.en:
Mrs. Phou T. is a widow with three children, one of whom is a garment factory worker while the other two study at the local school. She lives in Pris Leu village in Takeo province.

Mrs. Phou T. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. She is also a pig breeder.

Since this business is going well, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fifteen piglets for breeding.

She hopes to increase her income and improve her family’s living condition with this loan.

loans.use: To buy fifteen piglets for her pig breeding business.

loans.name: María Del Transito

texts.es: María del Transito C. D. B. D. 54 años D. edad, resiD. en Colón en el departamento D. La Libertad, junto a su esposo D. 60 años D. edad que se dedica a trabajar como comerciante. María del Transito tiene una venta D. frutas y verduras en la placita la bendición en Colón. Ella solícita un préstamo ya que desea poder comprar mas frutas y más verduras, puesto que desea mejorar las ganancias D. su negocio. María es una persona muy responsable y dedicada la cual se esfuerza mucho por tener una vida digna.
texts.en:
María del Transito C. D. B. is 54 years old, and lives in Colon (in the department of La Libertad) with her 60-year old husband, who works as a trader and merchant. Maria del Transito operates a stand selling fruits and vegetables in the La Bendicion market in Colon. She's requesting a loan to purchase more fruits and vegetables, which will allow her to increase her profits. Maria is a very responsible and dedicated person who works hard to live a positive, worthwhile life.

Translated from Spanish by Jim Muir, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim K. is a businessman in the northern city of Makeni. He has been selling used clothes for men for over twenty years now. About ten months ago, Ibrahim received his first SMT/Kiva loan which was the sum of SLL 2,000,000. With the help of that loan, Ibrahim has experienced a vast growth in his business and personal life. With the profit he made out of the business, the 38-year-old was better able to look after his 5 children and wife. 

Having completed repaid that loan successfully, he is again requesting a loan of SLL 3,000,000 to further strengthen his business. Born in Port Loko, northern Sierra Leone, Ibrahim finds Makeni a very suitable place to carry on his activity. He will use this loan to buy two bales of second-hand clothes, some bags of rice, and gallons of palm-oil. A bale of used clothes costs SLL 800,000 in Freetown, the capital city. Ibrahim can not specify how many bags of rice and gallons of palm-oil he will buy as prices for such commodities are not fixed.

loans.use: Buy two bales of used clothes, bags of rice, and gallons of palm-oil

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana O. has two children. She supports her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. She has received a senior high school education. 

Diana sells cooked rice with tomato sauce at Chapel Square near Elmina. She has been engaged in this business since 2001. Her loan will be used to buy more rice and ingredients to prepare food for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a house.

loans.use: to buy more rice and ingredients used to prepare food for sale

loans.name: Nurila's Group

texts.ru:
Кадырбаева Нурила – лидер данной группы. Нурила – из г. Кант. Слово кант в переводе с киргизского означает «сахар». Но, однако, в последние годы в городе жизнь оказалась не совсем сладкой. Многие жители города уехали на заработки в ближнее и дальнее зарубежье. Эта же судьба грозила и Нуриле. К тому же у неё с мужем четверо детей, которые только начали достигать юношеского возраста. Путешествовать с четырьмя детьми было бы нелегко и муж Нурилы, не раздумывая, решил заняться частным извозом. Нурила в свою очередь, на накопленные от заработной платы средства взяла в аренду контейнер и начала продавать продукты питания. Приобрести контейнер в родном городе не получилось, зато получилось в селе, которое находится в двадцати километрах от Канта. Дети уже подросли, а бизнес позволил им остаться в родном городе. Старшая дочь только окончила школу, а остальные дети всё ещё учатся в школе. В своё время Нурила вложила восемь тысяч сомов ($180), чтобы начать торговлю. Теперь она в месяц зарабатывает десять тысяч сомов ($220). Нуриле нужны средства, чтобы вложить их в закупку новой партии товара и увеличения товарооборота. Она надеется получить этот кредит и осуществить задуманное. В планы Нурилы также входит в ближайшем будущем купить домой мебель, и кое – какую живность.

У Нурилы три партнёра по группе:

Айжан сорок четыре года. Муж Айжан – строитель. Айжан – мать троих детей. Две дочери – замужем. Сын учится в школе. Айжан – домохозяйка. Она разводит скот, и продаёт его на скотном рынке. Айжан ежемесячно зарабатывает до десяти тысяч сомов. Сейчас она нуждается в кредите, чтобы купить бычка для откорма и продажи. 

Нуржан сорок шесть лет. Муж Нуржан работает электриком. У Нуржан одна дочь. Нуржан раньше занималась пошивом национальных изделий, но знакомые посоветовали ей заняться торговлей мукой. Нуржан решила попробовать и купила на накопленные средства несколько мешков и начала торговать. Нуржан нужен кредит, чтобы вложить средства в закупку муки. 

Гульнаре сорок лет. Муж Гульнары разводит скот. Гульнара торгует в с. Ивановка продуктами питания, конфетами и печеньем. Гульнара – мать троих детей. 
Все дети ходят в школу. Старший сын уже заканчивает в этом году школу. Гульнара просит предоставить ей кредит, чтобы купить несколько коробок конфет и печенья.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
K. Nurila is the leader of this group. She lives in the city of Kant. In translation from Kirghiz the word “kant” means “sugar”. However, in the past couple of years life in the city has been far from sweet. Many residents left the country in hope of finding stable employment elsewhere. The same fate was threatening Nurila and her husband. Additionally, they had four children to take care of. Traveling with them would have been uneasy at best and so Nurila’s husband decided to stay and become a taxi driver. Tapping into her savings, Nurila rented a container and started to sell foodstuffs. Finding a container in her home city proved problematic, however, they were able to rent one in a village twenty kilometers away. Her children had already grown and this business allowed them to remain in Kant. Her eldest daughter has already finished high school, while the rest of the children are still in school. In order to start her business, Nurila invested eight thousand soms ($180). Today her average monthly income is about ten thousand soms ($220). Nurila needs capital to invest into new products and increase her goods turnover. She also plans to buy some furniture and livestock for her household. Narila has three partners in her group: Aijan is forty-four years old. Her husband is a construction worker. They have three children. Their two daughters are married and her son is in school. Aijan is a housewife. She raises livestock and sells it on the market. She makes up to ten thousand soms per month. She is requesting a loan in order to buy bull to fatten and sell. Nurjan is forty-six years old. Her husband works as an electrician. She had tailored ethnic clothes and products but her friends recommended that she become a flour salesman. Nurjan decided to try it out and bought a couple bags of flour. Nurjan needs a loan to invest her capital in more flour. Gulnara is forty years old. Her husband raises livestock. Gulnara works in the village of Ivanovka where she sells foodstuffs, candy and cookies. She is a mother of three children, all of which are attending school. Her eldest son will graduate this year. Gulnara is asking for a loan to buy some boxes of cookies and candy. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy some household goods and groceries for the convenience store

loans.name: Kennedy

texts.en:
Kennedy is a 28-year-old married man with two children who both attend school. He has been running his retail shop, where he sells clothes, shoes, and various other items, for two years and was previously employed at City Council. His other source of income is from offering transport services with his motorbike.

With the KES 30,000 loan, Kennedy wants to purchase mobile phone accessories. He is grateful to Faulu Kenya for teaching him how to manage and maintain income from his business. He hopes to expand his boutique in the future and open up other businesses.

Kennedy describes himself as creative and loyal.

loans.use: To purchase mobile phone accessories for his shop

loans.name: Fatmeh

texts.en: Fatmeh started working as a private teacher in 2007 and has five years of experience in this occupation. She is a 25-year-old married woman and the mother of one young child. She has prepared a speciA. room in her house for teaching and she takes students from her town. Today, Fatmeh is asking to borrow $900 to buy a computer to facilitate her job process and preparations for the students.

loans.use: To buy a computer

loans.name: Julie

texts.en: "So far, my rice farm has been running smoothly, and I am grateful that it helps my family a lot," shares Julie M., a 45-year-old married woman with five children. She wants to have a happy home. Her children's education is one of her top priorities. She wants them to experience wellness in life. She just started preparing her land for the planting of rice crops. She said that she needs supplies for it. As a new member of CEVI, she now has access to its program. So, she requested a loan of 6000 PHP. With that amount, she can buy seeds, fertilizer, and other needed farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizer, and other needed farm supplies

loans.name: Estela

texts.en:
Estela S. is from the village of Maguikay, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 34 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Estela owns and operates a manufacturing business. The main source of income for the business comes from manufacturing and selling bamboo products, such as bamboo chairs (as seen in the picture), to local businesses and community members. Estela has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2008, Estela joined Kiva partner, GDMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This loan was used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. Estela is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional raw materials to expand her product offering. This loan will be her third from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw materials to expand her product offering
